title: Shannon Channel Capacity
formal_statement: For a communication channel with bandwidth B and signal-to-noise ratio SNR, the maximum reliable data rate (channel capacity) is: C = B log₂(1 + SNR) bits per second. Arbitrarily low error rates are achievable at rates below capacity; rates above capacity have irreducible error.
plain_language: There is a fundamental limit to how much information can be reliably transmitted through a noisy channel, determined by bandwidth and signal strength. You cannot exceed this limit regardless of coding scheme.
assumptions_scope: Continuous channel with unlimited bandwidth or discrete channel with defined capacity
Reliable communication means arbitrarily low error probability
typical_traps: Assuming arbitrarily low error rates are achievable at any transmission rate
Not recognizing that exceeding capacity guarantees errors
Believing clever coding eliminates the fundamental limit
Ignoring the bandwidth-SNR tradeoff in system design

escape_hatches.trade_offs: Energy cost; regulatory limits on power; physical constraints; interference with other systems
Spectrum is limited and regulated; interference; hardware complexity; cost

escape_hatches.description: Use optimal coding up to capacity
examples: Error-correcting codes (Turbo codes, LDPC, Polar codes)
Adaptive modulation based on channel conditions
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Computational complexity; latency from encoding/decoding; cannot exceed capacity

escape_hatches.description: Accept error floors or reduced rate
examples: Operate below capacity with simple codes
Tolerate higher error rates for applications that can handle them
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Reduced throughput or reliability; may not meet application requirements

test_or_check: Check if the claim requires reliable transmission at rates exceeding C = B log₂(1 + SNR) for given bandwidth and SNR. If arbitrarily low error rate claimed above capacity, flag as conflicting with Shannon limit.
references: Shannon, C. E. (1948). A Mathematical Theory of Communication. Bell System Technical Journal, 27(3), 379-423.
Cover, T. M., & Thomas, J. A. (2006). Elements of Information Theory (2nd ed.). Wiley-Interscience.
notes: Shannon's capacity theorem is one of the most important results in information theory and communications engineering. It provides both a fundamental limit and a constructive proof that this limit is achievable with appropriate coding.
